pullRequest.body:
Proves the following statements:
- if `0 â‰¤ a â‰¤ n` and `0 â‰¤ b â‰¤ n`, then `|a - b| â‰¤ n` (similarly with `|a - b| < n`)
- `0 < |a - b|` iff `a â‰  b`

---

~~The lemmas for `g ^ |i| = 1` iff `g ^ i = 1` are marked as simp, since the rewrite is strictly decreasing and may unlock later simplifications.~~ These have been outsourced to #10559

The lemmas for `0 < |a - b|` iff `a â‰  b` provide an easier-to-work-with form (`a â‰  b`), but since other similar lemmas are not marked as simp (eg. [Int.natAbs_pos](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Std/Data/Int/Order.html#Int.natAbs_pos)), I chose to not mark these ones as simp either.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #10559

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
I do not know where I can place `zpow_abs_eq_one_iff` as a lemma:
- `Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Basic.lean` does not have absolute values defined yet
- `Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Order.lean`  does not either
- `Mathlib/Algebra/Order/Group/Abs.lean` does have absolute values, but doesn't yet have an instance for `LinearOrderedAddCommGroup â„¤`, so I can't reason about absolute values in `zpow` there, unless if I add an ugly `[LinearOrderedAddCommGroup â„¤]` instance requirement
- `Mathlib/Data/Int/Order/Basic.lean` has all of the necessary imports, but placing lemmas about zpow of groups in this file feels wrong

> I do not know where I can place `zpow_abs_eq_one_iff` as a lemma:
> 
>     * `Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Basic.lean` does not have absolute values defined yet
> 
>     * `Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Order.lean`  does not either
> 
>     * `Mathlib/Algebra/Order/Group/Abs.lean` does have absolute values, but doesn't yet have an instance for `LinearOrderedAddCommGroup â„¤`, so I can't reason about absolute values in `zpow` there, unless if I add an ugly `[LinearOrderedAddCommGroup â„¤]` instance requirement
> 
>     * `Mathlib/Data/Int/Order/Basic.lean` has all of the necessary imports, but placing lemmas about zpow of groups in this file feels wrong

Does `#find_home` suggest better files?

When in doubt, feel free to start a new file.

Running `#find_home` of a copy of the lemmas after importing `Mathlib` makes it suggest `Mathlib.Data.Int.Order.Basic` (where it is currently). I'm also iffy at the idea of creating a dedicated module for it, since @YaelDillies just removed a week ago modules for lemmas that didn't need to be in separate modules anymore, so I'd like to first know what his opinion is on the issue

`zpow_abs_eq_one` can't be any earlier than `Data.Int.Order.Basic` because that's where the absolute value over `â„¤` is defined. `pow_natAbs_eq_one`, however, can move all the way up to `Algebra.Group.Basic` with a much simpler proof. Moving it there also helps golf a lemma.
Yeah, that looks definitely cleaner

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10559~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I think everything has been addressed here.

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8024330759/job/21922674099)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8024330759/job/21922673429)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8024330759/job/21922673969)
Looks good; one suggestion:
Looks good; one suggestion:
Do you need the `@`s here?
I remember I used to at some point in time, but now it seems to work without

```suggestion
theorem abs_sub_pos_iff_ne : 0 < |a - b| â†” a â‰  b :=
  âŸ¨fun h eq => lt_irrefl (0 : Î±) (by rwa [eq, sub_self, abs_zero] at h),
  fun h => lt_of_not_le (mt eq_of_abs_sub_nonpos h)âŸ©
```

Using up-arrows rather than type ascriptions can confuse lean (though probably never here); this is perhaps more readable and robust:
```suggestion
    natAbs (b - a : â„¤) â‰¤ n := by
```

```suggestion
    natAbs (b - a : â„¤) < n := by
```
Are there any theorem statements about `x + -y` in mathlib besides `sub_eq_add_neg`? Do you really need this variant?
`sub_eq_add_neg` isn't a `@[simp]`, so my reasoning was that by doing so I'd enable some simps. To be fair I can do this transformation at call site and scrap this variant alltogether

Perhaps:
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem abs_sub_nonpos_iff_eq : |a - b| â‰¤ 0 â†” a = b :=
  âŸ¨eq_of_abs_sub_nonpos, by rintro rfl; rw [sub_self, abs_zero]âŸ©

theorem abs_sub_pos_iff_ne : 0 < |a - b| â†” a â‰  b :=
  not_le.symm.trans abs_sub_nonpos_iff_eq.not
```
though I might drop the `iff_eq`/`iff_ne` suffixes as well:
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem abs_sub_nonpos : |a - b| â‰¤ 0 â†” a = b :=
  âŸ¨eq_of_abs_sub_nonpos, by rintro rfl; rw [sub_self, abs_zero]âŸ©

theorem abs_sub_pos : 0 < |a - b| â†” a â‰  b :=
  not_le.symm.trans abs_sub_nonpos_iff_eq.not
```
The lhs or `abs_sub_nonpos` simplifies to `a - b = 0`, so I can't really have it as `@[simp]`

```suggestion
    natAbs (a - b : â„¤) â‰¤ n := by
  rw [â† Nat.cast_le (Î± := â„¤), coe_natAbs]
  exact abs_sub_le_of_nonneg_of_le (ofNat_nonneg a) (Nat.cast_le.mpr a_le_n)
    (ofNat_nonneg b) (Nat.cast_le.mpr b_le_n)
```
Why do you switch the order of `a` and `b`?  Also, some of the implicit arguments can be automatically inferred.

Similar comments for the next lemma.
`Nat.cast_le` was giving me trouble with not being able to infer the target type before `.mpr` was called on it

```suggestion
theorem natAbs_sub_pos_iff {i j : â„¤} : 0 < natAbs (i - j) â†” i â‰  j := by
```
and you're missing the `ne_zero` version

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Small lemmas around |a - b| and Int.natAbs (a - b)
